Description: Finely fashioned bronze axe-head: it has been cleaned of corrosion product. Both sides are bevelled, the marks of grinding being plainly visible. The pattern of corrosion damage on the lugs has preserved the line of the original binding. The cutting edge shows signs of wear. There are light scratches all over the blade and a fairly deep gash in one face.
Curator's comments: Bibliography: E. Kühnert-Eggesbrecht, ‘Die Axt als Waffe und Werkzeug im alten Ägypten’ (Berlin, 1969), 111, G-IX/1, pl. XIV, 2.
Bibliographic references: Davies 1987 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities in the British Museum (158)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 1998/9 Oct-Jun, South Carolina, The Charleston Museum, Queens Commoners of the New Kingdom
Acquisition name: Purchased from: R J Moss & Co
